headline: Should President Obama have fired James Comey?
subHeadline: The debate continues on "The Fox News Specialists."

utterances.speaker: ERIC BOLLING, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Hello, everyone. I'm Eric Bolling, along with Eboni K. Williams and Kat Timpf, 5:00 will never be the same. We are "The Fox News Specialists." The firing of FBI director James Comey may be the most decisive act of the Trump young presidency so far. The move has set off a political firestorm across Washington and beyond, with Democrats in overdrive trying to gym up as much anger and outrage as they can, apparently forgetting their long running disdain for the ousted FBI chief. Today, President Trump gave his first on camera remarks about his decision.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Why did you fire Director Comey?

utterances.speaker: PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Because he wasn't doing a good job, very simply. He was not doing a good job.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: And the mainstream media is buzzing calling the firing, quote, a crisis and scandalous. Today, however, I spoke to several senior Trump administration officials and here's what can be reported as the real news, not the fake news, President Trump has been concerned about the effectiveness of James Comey for months, and when his attorney general and deputy attorney general recommended Comey's firing, he decided that was time to act and it's now, period. So let's bring in new guys and let's have a little discussion about that. A lot of partisan divide going on all day in the media today with the left saying this is scandalous. This is Watergate-type scandal. And the right saying, wait a minute, Trump has been talking about this for a long time.

utterances.speaker: EBONI K. WILLIAMS, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Yeah, sure, E, and I'm sure many on the right will confirm what you reported. There are 12 Republican senators now that you have concern. But first, let's bring it to yesterday. I mean, you live broke this story on the air as it was happening, and I don't know if you saw out of the corner of your eye, E, actually, was laughing a bit, and I thought you were joking. That's how astonish I was in that moment. I thought it was a joke. I thought it was a practical joke. And apparently, I wasn't the only one. Jim Comey, it's been reported, also thought it was so absurd he thought it was a prank. He was in Los Angeles, and then found out, no, indeed, it was very, very real.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: And boy, Kat, did it really blow up. All night, and spent the whole day, both sides duking it out. Your thoughts on where we stand now.

utterances.speaker: KATHERINE TIMPF, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Absolutely. Well, I think that everyone should be able to agree that it's good that he's gone. Because like you said, Democrats have had issues with him for a while, Republicans have issues with him. But the timing is interesting. It really is. It kind of makes me think you got into a fight with your boyfriend and you did something that was really bad and you thought you were going to break up, but then you didn't, then three months later he breaks up with you and says that's the reason. I would be saying, oh, really? You know, especially if there was some girl that he was a little close to, but even though you didn't have any actually proof of them colluding, you still might have questions.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: You've got to ask the question.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: We're going to break that down and find out exactly what we're talking about with the boyfriend and girlfriend thing. But first, there's been many fast-moving developments today, so joining us now with more from Washington, Fox News chief White House correspondent, John Roberts, break it down to us, John. Where are we?

utterances.speaker: JOHN ROBERTS, FOX NEWS CHIEF WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Eric, good afternoon. You mentioned at the top, and that really is the headline of the day, that the narrative is to how all of this came to pass really has changed quite dramatically in the last 24 hours. We were led to believe yesterday, and even as recently as this morning when the vice president was up on Capitol Hill and appear before the cameras that this really was a bottom up recommendation and operation. That this had come from the deputy attorney general Rod Rosenstein, who had looked into James Comey and come to the conclusion that he had lost the confidence of the FBI director and that he needed to be replaced. But now we're learning, as you mentioned at the top here, that President Trump has been thinking about this for an awful long time. In fact, Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the deputy press secretary, principal deputy press secretary, who was filling in for Sean Spicer today, said that the president has been thinking about this going all the way at least until just after the election. Listen to what she told us just a short time ago in the daily briefing.

utterances.speaker: SARAH HUCKABEE SANDERS, PRINCIPAL DEPUTY PRESS SECRETARY
utterances.sentences: The president had lost -- again, like I said, he's lost confidence in Director Comey, and frankly, he's been considering letting Director Comey goes since the day he was elected. But he did have a conversation with the deputy attorney general on Monday, where they had come to him to express their concern. The president asked that they put their concerns and their recommendation in writing.

utterances.speaker: ROBERTS
utterances.sentences: So clearly, they went through the appropriate procedure here. The deputy attorney general who is Jim Comey's boss gave a long -- it was a two and a half page long letter to the attorney general, Jeff Sessions, saying that he think that he had tried to usurp then attorney general Loretta Lynch's authority when he held that press conference back on July 5th of last year. The attorney general then sent that recommendation up to the president who then wrote that now famous letter of termination. But, Eric, what we're learning today was that this had a lot to do with the president as well. And if the president was thinking about firing Jim Comey on the ninth or the tenth of November, that means he must have been thinking about it a long time before that, potentially including when he's sang Jim Comey's praises after the October 28th decision to reopen the Hillary Clinton email investigation. So not sure if this goes all the way back to July 5 for the president or not, but it certainly seems to go back a lot further than we were initially led to believe. And while the president has been thinking about this for months, we are told by Sarah Huckabee Sanders that the big catalyst, the big part of the reason why Comey is gone happen when he was giving that testimony before the judiciary committee in the senate a week ago when he all but acknowledged, according to Sarah Huckabee, that he had thrown a stick of dynamite into the works at the FBI when it decided that he was going out there without permission back in July, and give that press conference. We talked at length about Clinton's emails, what she had done wrong, what she should have done, and the fact that he didn't see any reason for the department of justice to press charges, Eric.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: John Roberts in the White House, thank you very much, sir. Now let's meet today's specialist. He's known as America's leading populist conservative. He was a senior advisor to three American presidents, three, Nixon, Ford, and Reagan. He's the author of the new book, Nixon's White House Wars. But he specializes in collecting 19th century historic memorabilia. Pat Buchanan is here. And he's a veteran of the Kerry and Obama presidential campaigns. The author of the book, The Best Worst President, what the right gets wrong about Barack Obama, he's a media analyst, who teaches at New York University, and he specializes in defending independent journalism against politically powerful interests, Mark Hannah is here. We have a lot of set up. I want to get right to you, Pat, as I mentioned in the setup, I spoke to several, not one, not two, several senior White House officials and the feeling was the same. There's nothing to see here. This has been going on for a long time. And when attorney general Sessions and deputy attorney general said this is the time.

utterances.speaker: PAT BUCHANAN, FORMER PRESIDENTIAL SENIOR ADVISER
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: President Trump took decisive and divisive action and said it's time to fire Comey.

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: He was advised to do something he wanted to do. That's right. My feeling on this, Eric, is that Trump has real exasperation with the fact that he's had a ten month investigation that alleges that his campaign was involved with Vladimir Putin to fix this election and that's why he won the election, and it's gone on for five or six months after the election was over. There's a cloud hanging over Trump's administration, White House unjustified, and I think he was telling, in effect, telling Comey, look, get this done. Get it over with. Exonerate me or indict somebody come. And I think Comey didn't do a thing and that's why he got rid of him.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Go ahead, Mark.

utterances.speaker: MARK HANNAH, AUTHOR
utterances.sentences: Yeah. Well, I'm happy to see that Pat Buchanan is not taking the White House's word for it. He's saying it's not about this Hillary Clinton email scandal, that, you know, the Trump administration saw the writing on the wall. The FBI was investigating the Russian scandal. This comes just days after Director Comey had asked the deputy attorney general for more resources to investigate.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: That's been refuted by the DOJ, for the record.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: Yeah. And they're going to, but on the same day. And this just smells bad. On the same day the grand jury started issuing subpoenas. The White House can say this has nothing to do with the Russia probe. You can believe them if you want. For me, it reeks of abuse of power. It seems downright Nixonian.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: And Eboni, President Trump letter yesterday.

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: Is that a personal insult?

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: . once my attorney general and my deputy attorney general's said I don't have confidence anymore, he made the decision.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And I can accept that, E. I can actually accept that language from the White House. Here's my only issue, let's break down this timeline. When exactly was there a loss of confidence? That's the $40,000 question. Was it back in July, when Comey politicized, I think, the FBI in that, you know, ridiculous and unnecessary statement, perhaps in an effort to save Loretta Lynch, whatever. Was it in October, when he put the letter out? Reopening the Hillary Clinton investigation? Or was it when president -- then, candidate Trump said what Comey did took guts and he was praising him. I'm just not exactly sure, E. All I have to say, when was the lost of confidence?

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: You know, buildup of.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: I personally want to ask Jeff Sessions that -- because on October 28, he said, and I quote, that Comey, quote, had an absolute duty, in my opinion, 11 days or not, to come forward with new information that he's -- and let the American people know that. So, on October 28th, he's defending it. And now, he's listing it as a reason that Comey has got to be fired. So where was the switch and why? I think that I would like to hear from Jeff Sessions because there's a huge difference between defending and then saying, yeah, actually it was so bad that he's got to be fired.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: So let me ask you this, let me ask you.

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Patrick, the DOJ oversees the FBI. Therefore, Jeff Sessions is James Comey's boss.

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: If the boss loses confidence in his senior FBI.

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: Look, James Comey is appointed for ten years. He works for the government of the United States. The head of the government of the United States is Donald Trump. He's lost confidence in the guy. He watches the guy sit there and investigate and investigate, says why aren't you removing this cloud over my head? A third of the country things we're complicit with Putin, and you haven't done it, and I don't like it. Here are some other arguments, still.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: Please.

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: . and you're gone. I mean, so what?

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: When was the last time a sitting president ousted somebody who was investigating -- a politically independent body investigating official corruption? Do you know when that was?

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: Sure, I was involved.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: You were in the White House.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: Firing Archibald Cox. When he was on his trail.

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: I was in the oval office with Richard Nixon. We've cut a deal. We thought Richardson were going to turn over documents over to Archibald Cox. He subpoenaed the tapes. He wouldn't accept the documents. Richardson was with us. I was in the oval office, I told the president, you've got to fire Archibald Cox. You've got to fire Richardson. The reason being, Henry Kissinger was in Moscow. It was the time of the Yom Kippur War. The Russians and the Americans were eyeball to eyeball. Nixon told me flat out, I can't have -- see me have a Cabinet officer reject what I'm doing. I have to get rid of him.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: That was Russian influence.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: One second, Mark.

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: One final line on that, Nixon said if I have to, I'll go down to a GF-7 to file that down.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And the distinction on what Pat is saying here, that I hear, is that there was immediate and swift action on that basis. And I accept that. And that make complete sense to me. That's different though, and I think the competing narrative we're hearing out of the Trump White House, E, which is partly that Comey was fired for what he did back in July or the mishandling of the investigation, versus this investigation around Russia.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: I'm about to tell you what the senior official said, Kat, they said it's been -- he's had questions about Comey since.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: And that's fine.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: Why did Sean Spicer, seven days ago say Donald Trump had full confidence in James Comey? Was he lying to us in the media?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: OK, listen. The most specific issue I think is how could Jeff Sessions say that this was defensible, defended, then the next day listed as a reason for the firing?

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Maybe deputy attorney general says.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: But he just not say, oh, I don't know about this. He said he had a duty, an absolute duty to report it. Now he's saying he has to be fired because of it. And you have a lot of reasons. Just skip that reason then.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Can I agree with our lefty, Mark Hannah, on one thing.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: Please do.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: I think the White House communications department dropped the ball on this. I really do think that they could have framed this better, they could frame it throughout better, and certainly I would have liked to see a little bit more -- I don't know, gusto, Pat.

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: You know what you should have done -- you've got to know you're going to have a mini firestorm when you get rid of this fellow. What he should have done is lineup some really top-flight guy that you're going to appoint, and then the fellow goes one day and you've got the new nominee, and that's the big story. Trump goes out in the press room and announces a new guy, Ray Kelly or Bratton type folks, and everybody says isn't this wonderful, we've got another Gorsuch.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I don't know that everybody would say that, Pat.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: He's used in firing people on TV as somebody said. But this is another time he's firing somebody.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Have somebody behind -- or, Kat, may -- help me out here, don't break up with your girlfriend unless you have another one?

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Guess what? The good news is we have a lot more on this. With Comey gone, the left is now demanding a special prosecutor in the Russia investigation, but the right is fighting back. Fireworks in the district of Columbia, so what else is new? Stay right here. Right there, right here, stay wherever, Eboni, Kat, and I will be right back with todays special.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: FBI Director Comey's removal has the Democrats frantically demanding the appointment of a special prosecutor for the Russia investigation.

utterances.speaker: SEN. CHUCK SCHUMER, D-N.Y., SENATE MINORITY LEADER
utterances.sentences: I have said from the get-go that I think a special prosecutor is the way to go. But now with what's happened it is the only way to go, only way to go to restore the American people's faith. Are people going to suspect cover up? Absolutely. If an independent special prosecutor is appointed, there still can be some faith that we can get to the bottom of this. If not, everyone will suspect cover-up.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Let's go now to Fox News chief intelligence correspondent Catherine Herridge. She joins us from Washington.

utterances.speaker: CATHERINE HERRIDGE, FOX NEWS CHIEF INTELLIGENCE CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Earlier today, we spoke with a former FBI agent who was directly involved in the Clinton email probe and we asked about the impact of the FBI director's termination on the Russia case, and he used this comparison. It's kind of like the train leaving the station, once it left the station, there's really nothing you can do to stop it, not even the termination of the FBI director, and that was the same attitude at the White House earlier today.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: We don't think it's necessary. You've got a house committee, a senate committee, and the department of justice all working on this. I don't think that there's the necessary need at this point to add that. You've got the deputy attorney general who I would say is about as independent as it comes due to the fact that he has such bipartisan support.

utterances.speaker: HERRIDGE
utterances.sentences: And the White House -- they're talking about the need for a special prosecutor. What we also learned today in that White House briefing is more about why the FBI director was fired in the first place. The White House said that when last year, he went around the attorney general, Loretta Lynch, and he made that very public statement in July against -- recommending against criminal charges for the apparent mishandling of classified information by Clinton and her team. They said it was like throwing a bomb into the justice department which is right across the street from where I'm standing right now. And then, what amplified that is Comey's testimony last week before the senate where he said he stood by that decision, and he did not accept that it was in fact a fatal error in this case. We've also learned that one of the other factors was his misstatement to congress about the Clinton email probe where he said thousands of emails were found on the laptop of Anthony Weiner, in a separate criminal case. Weiner's connection to all of this is that he's the estranged husband of longtime Clinton aid, Huma Abedin. The FBI had to correct the record in a written statement saying that the number was far less, but all of that came together to create a lack of confidence in the director. Back to you.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Thank you. All right, we're going to bring our specialist in. I'm going to ask you, first, Mr. Buchanan, what do you think that Donald Trump's attitude should be toward this special prosecutor?

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: An independent console or special prosecutor, no. The FBI is investigating an intelligence failure, intelligence breach in the United States. If a crime is discovered by the FBI and it affects people high in the Trump administration or in their campaign, I think then you talk about who's going to prosecute it. But unless and until you get a crime, this is the point I've been trying to make, they've had ten months of this. Please give us somebody who colluded with Putin. And they can't come up with a single name.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: I'm getting a sense you might disagree.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: I know that the FBI was just decapitated, so it's going to be hard for them to produce evidence. But it does look like the FBI.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Why? Why do they have 150 agents working on this? A 150.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: Come on.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: . trying to prove collusion.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: First of all, you and I don't know what the FBI knows.

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: Mark, we do know. Clapper said there's no collusion.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: Pat, I have a tremendous amount of respect for you.

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: . the CIA said.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: You're a political legend. Do you buy, for a minute, that the White House let Comey go because all of a sudden there was a revelation that Comey bypassed Loretta Lynch a year ago, and this was a decisive act to protect the honor of Hillary Clinton? Where's Hillary Clinton -- the White House for this act of gallantry.

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: Let me agree with you. I don't think he's tipped off with what Comey did to Hillary Clinton at all. I think he was delighted and said so. But I'll tell you what he saw.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: He said it was courageous, and now he's firing him for it.

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: Yesterday, and before, what he saw is, I've got a guy that's investigating ten months and has come up with nothing, and he's proven to be a loose cannon going up there and letting, you know, all about the emails and everything with Huma Abedin. I don't like him. I'm going to get this loose cannon out of there. And, OK, call the justice department.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: OK, Eric.

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: . tell them to give me a couple of reason.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: I want to get your reaction real quick on something else, something else, really quick. All the Democratic outrage over Comey's firing kind of seems like a massive flip from their nonstop Comey bashing almost a year ago. SEN. CHUCK SCHUME, D-N.Y., OCT. 30, 2016: When I heard about it, I found it hard to believe that Comey, who I thought had some degree of integrity, would do this. What Comey did, I just respectfully disagree with my opponent. What he did was appalling. And prosecutors from one end of America to another know it. REP. NANCY PELOSI, D-CALIF, NOV. 2, 2016: I think he made a mistake on this. And he clearly has a double standard when it comes to Donald Trump. And these jobs, if you're not in it for a while, you can't take the heat, and I think he just couldn't take the heat from the Republicans. SEN. HARRY REID, D-NEV., DEC. 10, 2016: I'm so disappointed in Comey. He has let the country down for partisan purposes, and that's why I'm calling him J. Edgar Hoover because I believe that.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Do you believe Jim Comey should resign, Senator Reid?

utterances.speaker: REID
utterances.sentences: Of course, yes.  JOHN PODESTA, CLINTON CAMPAIGN CHAIR, NOV. 6, 2016: I'm not challenging Mr. Comey's motivation, but I do think it was unwarranted, it was a mistake, and I think that Republican and Democratic former justice department officials have come out and questioned the move that he made.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: OK, I can't even hold it any longer. Chuck Schumer and Nancy Pelosi have got to be the two worst examples to put up there and talk about consistency on the issue of Jim Comey. Let's just be very clear and let's all remember correctly that until yesterday about 5:00 something in the afternoon, nobody had anything particularly good, warm, or fuzzy to say about Jim Comey. I don't think anyone is particularly sad to see him go on merit alone. But I do want to point this out. I don't think it's just -- I think that's not fair or accurate to say that it's just the left that has these questions or concerns. Republican senator, Jeff Flake, from Arizona said, specifically, I've got a lot -- I took the last several hours trying to figure out an acceptable rationale for the timing of Comey's firing and I just can't do it. And I think when he says that -- and John McCain has said something similar, so 12 GOP senators.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: When you talk about who John McCain, and Flake, and Lindsey Graham, of course they are. They're the ones who are asking for a special prosecutor. They're anti-Trumpers. You can't.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Let me finish. It's not just Schumer. It's Pelosi. It's Harry Reid. It's Adam Schiff. It's Elijah Cummings, Steve Cohn -- Senator Tim Kaine, Dianne Feinstein.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: Finally, Donald Trump taking their advised.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: . on and on of people who are calling for Jim Comey to be fired or to step down. Now he gets fired and they say, hey, what's all this stuff with Trump? It's such liberal hypocrisy that they keep saying.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: Does the timing not matter?

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: None, whatsoever.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: By your account, Eric, the White House couldn't produce a rational, reasonable, coherent, cogent explanation for why they fired the guy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You know what? I think Pat Buchanan gave us a better explanation than we got from the White House.

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: Trump did a terrible thing by firing in May an individual that Schumer thought should be fired in October. Why is Schumer upset about the timing?

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: It lacks all credibility. The Trump White House has enough of a cloud hanging over.

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: They're going to get a new FBI director that Schumer can support far more than Comey.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: It backfired, big time, politically.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: All right, well.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: . otherwise.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: We have to move on. Will Americans faith in the FBI be restored after the firing of James Comey? How the agency can shed its politically toxic reputation, next. Also, make sure to follow us on social media @specialistsfnc on both Twitter and Facebook.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: The FBI's reputation with Americans has taken a huge beating over the last year. And James Comey's announcement last July of bringing no charges against Hillary Clinton over her email scandal, well, that could be a major cause of the blame.

utterances.speaker: JAMES COMEY, FORMER FBI DIRECTOR
utterances.sentences: Although there is evidence of potential violations of the statutes regarding the handling of classified information, our judgment is that no reasonable prosecutor would bring such a case.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But with Comey now ousted from his job, what should be done to restore Americans' faith at such a critical institution?  E., I'm going to start with you on this.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Can I just jump in very quickly? I'll let the table take this. But what Comey said right there is very important and probably the reason why he got fired. He went -- the FBI is an investigative body, not a prosecutorial body. What he said right there was a recommended course of action for a prosecutor. And he became political by using his prosecutorial hat when he should've just kept with the investigative hat. He would have been fine. He lost the confidence of his own agents, and I think when he therefore became ineffective as an investigator.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think you're exactly right. I think in that exact moment, E., he politicized the FBI...

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: ... in a way in which -- I hope they recover. I don't know that they will. Now this is -- I'm going to come to you on this, Pat. This is what people are saying. They're saying that he did that as a way of protecting Loretta Lynch. That just a week prior to that, Loretta Lynch had that horrible meeting with Bill Clinton on the tarmac. We all heard about it. Her credibility was just in shambles. And so, as opposed to making her -- and she should have been the one to make that call; Eric's exactly right. Instead of putting her in that position, this is him taking that bullet for her. Does that make it any better? Do you even buy that?

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: I think, you know, Loretta Lynch should have dropped out of it, but the deputy attorney general, Eric, is correct. FBI director, he's got all the information. He turns it over to -- to the No. 2 guy at Justice. They make the call as to whether or not to prosecute. The FBI does not make those decisions.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: They don't.

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: It's an investigative body.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: They don't.

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: And I think he went out there, and excuse me, he was a big hotdog out there. And of course, he laid all this garbage on Hillary at the same time says, "We're not going to prosecute."

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: Can I add -- can I add? Because I want to know: so is that where he went wrong? Yes, right there in that moment?

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: He went wrong there.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: Do you think President Obama should have fired him?

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: At that point, I think President Obama would've killed Hillary's campaign if he fired him.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But should have.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: Do you think you should have gotten fired? He would have gotten so much blowback from people like you, on the right, which...

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: Look, I was not enthusiastic about...

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: You would have been saying, "Why would you corrupt the independence of the director of the FBI?"

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: Look, I was...

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: Right now, when Trump does it, everybody's defending him.

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: I was stunned by what the -- you know, Director Comey did when he came out there and, in effect, laid out a case for her indictment and then said no prosecutor is going to indict.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: Eric do you think President Obama should have fired -- should he have fired Comey right there?

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Why would he? Why would President Obama fire Comey when he was laying right -- he was laying a gift at the altar of Hillary Clinton.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I will tell you why, Eric Bolling. He should have fired him, because it was the wrong thing to do; because in that moment Jim Comey did a job that is out of his bounds. It is out of bounds.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Well, I'll tell you what he would have done. If he did, if President Obama did fire Jim Comey, it would've saved the left a lot of heartache and Donald Trump a lot of headaches.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: Look, yes. John -- James Comey has caused a lot of heartache for the left and the right, but that's because he doesn't look at the world through left and right, conservative, liberal. He looks through justice and injustice, legal and illegal.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: OK, let me ask -- let me ask you. You think he did a good job, thought? Nobody can say he did a good job, even what he did last week, messing up and saying thousands of emails when it was...

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: I think -- I think he showboated. I think he showboated.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Ten.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: As if Huma Abedin needed any more bad press.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Exactly. That's a huge difference.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: As a Hillary Clinton supporter, he ticked me off to no end. He went out ahead of his skis; he did all these things. All the -- on both sides.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: You don't have to be bad at your job with a partisan slant to be bad at your job. You can just be plain bad at your job. And I think that Comey is an example of that.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: He didn't get fired -- he didn't get fired because he was bad for his job -- bad at his job.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: I have the same concerns with you about the timing.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: He got -- he got fired -- Kat, do you think he got fired because he was bad at his job or because he was onto something with this Russia probe, gathering evidence?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: I'm all about investigating, and I have the same concerns as you about timing.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: So do you think -- do you think Congress should appoint a special prosecutor?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: I don't have answers. I have questions.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: Do you think, yes or no?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: I think that Trump should even want that.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: Special prosecutor?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: It's not going to leave. It's not going to leave him. I think that...

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: Do you think, Eric, that they should...

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Absolutely not. We have a House investigation. We have a Senate investigation. We have a Department of Justice investigation. And we have some -- we have a group of FBI...

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: Those guys all report to the president of the United States.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: ... who have worked on this case for ten months already.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: They're all reporting to President Trump.

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: ... arrogated to himself a power and authority he did not have when he exonerated Hillary of an indictment.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: ... and said, "Here's all the evidence."

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: Hey, you know what? Your guy, J. Edgar Hoover, when Nixon was president, he did the same exact thing. You know how he got let go? He died right before the Watergate investigation. You guys never fired him for doing the same exact thing.

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: Read my book. I've got a memo to Nixon recommending the retirement of J. Edgar Hoover a year before his death.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: There you go.

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: There you go.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: I'll buy your book. I'll buy your book, Pat.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: At least Pat Buchanan was on it. President Trump hosting Russia's foreign minister in the Oval today, amid the Comey uproar. Is a thaw in relations between both countries ahead? Stay with us.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Welcome back to "The Fox News Specialists." Our specialists today are Mark Hannah and Pat Buchanan. If all this drama surrounding James Comey wasn't enough, President Trump hosted Russia's foreign minister at the White House today. The meeting was preplanned, but of course, that isn't stopping the conspiratorial chatter among the left. Eboni, it was preplanned under the -- under the heading "you can't make this stuff up."

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Russia, Russia, Russia.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Not only was Sergey Lavrov here, Sergey Kislyak, the very guy who was at the center of all the controversy around General Flynn. General Flynn met with him and caused all the problems. He was at the White House today, as well.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes, it's like a "Rocky" script or something. I mean, this is really insane. Pre-planned, so technically, President Trump and the administration can't help the optics of this; they cannot help the timing. But it doesn't help also that American journalists weren't allowed to get in there and get pictures. And the only picture we do have comes from our friends, the Russians.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Kat, on the crazy timing of this. As he -- let me ask you this: Do you think it had anything to do with Comey's firing yesterday?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: No, there are so many people saying Trump meeting with this Russian leader amid these questions about collusion. We really should just say Trump meeting with this Russian leader amid being the president, because that's what you do when you're the president. It's good that he's working on relations with Russia. That's a good thing. The timing is bad, but what was he going to do? Cancel it? That makes it look like he has something to hide.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Yes, but Pat Buchanan, someone else showed up at the White House today. Henry Kissinger showed up and said hello and shook the hand of Sergey Lavrov.

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: I think Henry, on these issues, Henry would be giving him good advice. But let me say, I'm delighted the president met with the Russians. Quite frankly, there's issues far more important than Comey. It's Syria, and it's whether we're going to send new troops into Afghanistan to fight. I think we've got to talk to the Russians. I know they're bad folks, but I was with old Richard Milhous and with Ronald Reagan when they met with Gorbachev and met with Brezhnev. You have to do it. That's the world, Eric.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Yes, I agree with you. Mark, your thoughts on this new -- let's call it new opening the relationship with Russia.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: Thawing. The reset, maybe, of...?

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: The thing that ticked me off was Sergey Lavrov walking into the White House, talking to American reporters. And they said, "Oh, what do you think about the Comey firing?" And he kind of, like, winked and nodded and said, "Oh, he was fired?" like, in a sarcastic...

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That was cute. That was cute.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: ... dismissive way. So, you know, I don't think the Russians...

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: That's Trump's fault, too?

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: Let me guess: I bet it was Sergey Lavrov that asked him to fire Comey, right? No. But I do think the optics -- the thing that really bothers me about this, though, is how did -- the heck did the Russian media get into the White House meeting with the Russian foreign minister? Why weren't the American press -- I know Donald Trump hates the press, much like Richard Nixon hated the press. I know he's thin-skinned; I know he's insecure when it comes to fake news and all this stuff. But why weren't American journalists in there again? Why is he so secretive?

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Afterwards, Mark, there was a quick press conference.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: I think that American journalists should have been in there.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Kat.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: I agree with that point.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: Do you agree with that, Pat?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: But I agree that I also think that the optics here were a bit...

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: You've got a meeting with Lavrov. In due respect, we know what the American journalists are going to ask: "What about Comey, Mr. President?" This is a meeting with the Russian foreign minister.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: Conducting important things (ph).

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: There are things more important that have every press opportunity. I think, as the director of communications for a president, I think he did the right thing.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: I think the optics were bad, and that could have made them a little better.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: American journalists.

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: Sometimes there are things more important than optics.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: We have even more. Even more show coming up. Democrats are decrying James Comey's firing as the worst thing since Watergate. Fortunately, Pat Buchanan, who was actually in the Nixon White House during the scandal, the Watergate scandal, is one of our specialists today. And he'll set them straight, next.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: The firing of James Comey still drawing an onslaught of comparisons from the left to Richard Nixon's Saturday Night Massacre during the Watergate scandal. For example, a former speechwriter for Bill Clinton is quoted by saying to Politico, quote, "This has every appearance of a cover-up, a possible act of obstruction of justice, just as much as Nixon firing Archibald Cox. That's the only comparable historical precedent I can think of." Well, we are so fortunate here today. We have one of our specialists, Pat Buchanan, who actually worked for the Nixon White House during Watergate. And you say these comparisons are just way off base.

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: I mean, the -- look, the Saturday Night Massacre occurred in a week after the vice president of the United States resigned during the Yom Kippur War, in which Israel was in desperate straits, and Nixon bailed them out and we had negotiations with the Soviets. And they were talking about moving nuclear weapons through the Bosporus. And this occurred in the middle of it, and Nixon had to fire him, as I say. And I recommended Arch -- I mean, Elliot Richardson, because he refused an order to fire Cox when he had told us that he would do it. And that's why we went ahead. So he had no other choice. As I say, I was sitting in the Oval Office with him, and he was very calm about it and serious about it. And he did say about Archibald Cox -- it was a rough quote -- "We can't have that biker sleeping in the bed with us."

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: How -- how about that, Mark? I mean, Mr. Buchanan is laying out a very detailed timeline. Everything, to me, sounds very connected. Do we have that in the Trump case with the firing of Comey?

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: Well, what was Archibald Cox doing? He was investigating the White House. He was -- he was leading up the White House -- excuse me, the -- he was basically investigating the Nixon administration. And so yes. You can -- I don't know. Look, I think that the whole thing just reeks of conspiracy. And I think there is absolutely a comparison to be made between Archibald Cox's firing and James Comey. It's the only other person who was investigating political corruption...

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: But look...

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: ... in the 20th Century to be fired by a sitting president.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: It's so funny to hear...

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: And look how that -- look how that happened -- look how that turned out.

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: But I knew how it would turn -- we knew how it was going to turn out. I went out to dinner that night...

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: You knew that Richard Nixon would resign in disgrace?

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: I knew what was going to happen. I went out to dinner that very night, Saturday night, and told friends of mine there will be an impeachment resolution in the House on Tuesday, and there were 20 of them. We knew it.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: I think comparisons between Nixon and Trump were hilarious, just because Nixon was such a skilled politician. Obviously, it didn't work out in the end. He was a skilled politician.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: Pat, before the end, was he a little paranoid?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Trump has been a politician for, like, a couple of months. Just of all the people, just because this one incident. Comparisons all day long.

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: Back to your point -- about your point, Henry Kissinger said, you know, "Sometimes paranoids have real enemies."

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Yes, and that was -- "X-Files." That was a great line in "The X- Files," as well. First of all, I'd like to say how thrilled I am that Pat Buchanan is here, because he was in the White House, the Nixon White House when this was going on. But Mark -- and Pat, weight in if you want. Archibald Cox was onto something. He knew -- he found a tie to Nixon. He found it; he knew it. He was asking them to be produced, and therefore, he was fired as he was on to something. Comey and the FBI have absolutely nothing.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: We don't know.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: What makes you say that?

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: We do know.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: They just asked for more resources.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: There is no proof.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: He just wrote a memo to the guy who fired him.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Stop. We have to say this. We have to say this. There is no evidence of collusion. Period, full stop now.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: The truth is, there is no evidence of collusion, E. But what we've heard Clapper say is that they don't have any proof.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: The difference is Archibald Cox had proof.

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: Well, there's no doubt about it. Look, we decapitated the White House staff. Two attorney generals were under investigation. There were tapes. John Dean had testified, linking Nixon to Watergate. So you had allegations of a real crime. That's why you needed a special prosecutor. But with Trump right now, there's no evidence of any crime. Please give us some.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: He's creating -- he's creating an environment. Did you read the letter where Trump fired Comey? He basically said, "Even though you personally told me on three occasions that I'm not being investigated..." It was a complete non-sequitur.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: That was bizarre. That was bizarre. Everyone has to admit that was bizarre.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: Yes. It sounds so self-conscious.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Very intentional.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: And guess what? It was statement of fact and probably the most relevant fact in this whole -- this whole ball of controversy.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: No, you're not being investigated...

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Mark -- let me -- Mark, let me get in here.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: This is important. Because I would submit, clearly, we know that Archibald Cox was further along, at least, in his investigation than Jim Comey. Also, targets change. So just because we don't have a lot of evidence right now. But right? As investigations go, you have to follow the evidence. Right?

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: Right. But the very fact that Trump put in there "Three times you've told me I'm not under investigation..."

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: At this moment.

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: ... I will say that that is Trumpian. Isn't that out there?

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: Not Nixonian. Not Nixonian.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Remember that doctor's note? Remember that doctor's note when he was running about he was just in the best health ever? That was -- kind of reminded me of that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Another Trumpism. All right. Don't go away. When we come back, we circle back with our specialists, Mr. Pat Buchanan and Mark Hannah. More after this.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Time for our daily segment, "Circle Back," where we return to a point made by one of our specialists earlier in the show, or Eric, Eboni and I get answers to any questions we are dying to ask them. All right, Mr. Buchanan, I know you're very, very big on the "no special prosecutor, nothing to see here." But you can't deny that this is not going to go away on its own, even in terms of optics. What would you -- how should Trump handle this?

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: He should appoint a really top-notch guy to be FBI director and get him confirmed and then give him a deadline to come up with an answer as to whether or not there was collusion in the main investigation. Did they collude with the Russians? If not, remove that cloud from the head of the president of the United States, because it looks to me like it's been put there totally unjustifiably.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: I hear Sally Yates is available. Maybe she should be at the top of the FBI.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: To get fired twice. Can I -- can I do my "Circle Back"?

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: Please.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: My "Circle Back" goes to Eboni. A lot of names of -- not the interim but the actual future director of the FBI. One name jumps out at me, and frankly he hasn't been a pro-Trump guy. So that -- you want to talk about...

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Can't wait to hear this name.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: ... nonpartisan. He's partisan, but it would be non-partisan in the Trump world. Trey Gowdy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You know what?

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: What a great prosecutor he has been, and what a great investigator he will be.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So I actually like Trey Gowdy. I don't think he's perfect by any means, but generally speaking, he has a great prosecutorial spirit. I say that as an attorney. But I think he's getting a lot of pushback, and a lot of people do consider him quite partisan. But my "Circle Back" is to Mr. Buchanan. When we look at Donald Trump's success as a candidate, and we talk about how his candidacy really came about in this antiestablishment way...

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: ... do you think Donald Trump finished what you clearly and incredibly started many years ago?

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: Well, I think he's got a lot of issues that matured by the time he came here. But look, he won this on his own. He came to his views on economic nationalism at the same time I did, way back when. He did a tremendous job. And look, whatever you say about the guy, he stood up to some of the worst -- worse beatings than Nixon ever had. I've never seen someone take a beating like that in the campaign, day in and day out, and smile and come through it. Really, I mean, you've got to credit the guy for that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I thought you did a fantastic job standing up to some establishment types in your day. So thank you.

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: Well, thank you.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Some other names: Ray Kelly.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Um-unh. No.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Chris Christie.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Chris Christie, no way.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: And the one that -- David Clarke.

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: He'd have to be confirmed by Congress.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So more people can die in David Clarke's jails as he proceeds over them?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Sorry.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Ooh.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Too much truth?

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Come on, Eboni.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I mean, too much truth? Too much truth? You know, he could have given the guy a bottle of water or something.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Chris Christie, could you imagine? That's -- all right. Yes, that would be really...

utterances.speaker: HANNAH
utterances.sentences: Definitely good for the prestige and the credibility of the FBI. Right? That's exactly what...

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: He can't get invited anywhere to do anything anymore. All right. Thank you to our "Fox News Specialists" today: Pat Buchanan, author of "Nixon's White House Wars," and Mark Hannah, author of "The Best Worst President." We thank you all for watching and make sure to follow us on social media, @SpecialistsFNC on Twitter and Facebook. Remember, 5 o'clock will never be the same. "Special Report" is next.
